Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Neurogenetic Framework of Condition-dependent Mate Choice
Award.AbstractNarration:
A major goal of evolutionary biologists is to determine how closely related species keep from interbreeding. This is often a result of differences in behavior, such as when females of two species differ in their preferences for particular mates. These preferences can be highly sensitive to changes in the environment. The aim of this study is to discover how female preferences in swordtail fish are affected by different environmental factors. This study is among the first to attempt to assess how the environment affects the molecular basis of sensory perception and mating behavior. Furthermore, this study will shed light on how environmental conditions can promote interbreeding and therefore affect how species split apart and come together. Throughout the course of this study, the researchers will train undergraduate students at Texas A&M as well as local students from Calnali, Mexico. These students will help in conducting experiments, thereby receiving a firsthand experience with research and becoming well-rounded scientists. This training will increase interest in ecology an evolutionary biology and, in the case of Calnali, will create exemplary scientists in a region where there are few.

Specifically, the researchers will use the swordtail fish Xiphophorus birchmanni to determine which genes in the brain and sensory tissue are sensitive to changes in female diet and her social environment, and how these environmental factors affect female preference for males of the same species. Newborn swordtails will be submitted to one of three social treatments (raised with adult conspecifics, adult heterospecific Xiphophorus malinche, or no adult exposure) and one of two diet treatments, varying in protein content, which has been shown to affect the strength of female swordtail preference. Upon maturation, female preference for conspecific versus heterospecific male odors will be assessed using a dichotomous mate choice assay. Female brains and olfactory epithelia will then be dissected and undergo RNA-Seq analyses to quantify gene expression. The researchers will then use in situ hybridization on candidate genes found from RNA-Seq to identify where these genes are expressed and therefore what brain regions are implicated in female mate choice. Tissue samples and extracted RNA will be archived in the Texas A&M University Biodiversity Research and Teaching Collections. Whole specimens will be accessioned to the Ichthyology collection of UNAM, Mexico. Data collected will be backed up on two workstations and a dedicated external drive. Data associated with accepted manuscripts will be archived in appropriate electronic repositories.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research supported by the NSF Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Grant examined how early learning and nutritional condition can affect olfactory mating preferences and gene expression in the olfactory epithelia and brain of female swordtails (Xiphophorus birchmanni).

While swordtails attend to both visual and olfactory cues when selecting mates, in the wild, female X. birchmanni typically rely on olfactory cues to preferentially choose males of their own species over those of the closely related sister species, Xiphophorus malinche. However, this preference has been shown to be dependent on the social experiences a female has throughout development. Specifically, female X. birchmanni raised with adults of their own species learn to prefer males of the same species, while those raised with adult heterospecifics eventually prefer the olfactory signals of male X. malinche.

Furthermore, certain olfactory preferences in X. birchmanni have been shown to be dependent on a female’s own nutritional status. Specifically, hungry females show relatively stronger olfactory preferences for well-fed males than well-fed females do. The goals of this study were to determine 1) whether female X. birchmanni show any innate olfactory preference for males of their own species, 2) whether this preference is affected by diet, and 3) the differences in gene expression profiles of female brains and olfactory tissue according to social exposure treatment.

We confirmed previous findings that female X. birchmanni learn to prefer male olfactory signals of the species they’re familiar with. Specifically, those raised with adult conspecifics preferred the odors of male X. birchmanni over X. malinche, while those raised with adult heterospecifics preferred the odors of male X. malinche. Importantly, we found that females raised in the absence of adults showed no net preference for either odor, suggesting that learning may actually be necessary for the development of olfactory preferences in this system. Furthermore, we found no significant differences in the strengths of preferences according to diet, suggesting that diet-sensitive preferences in this system may be dependent on the cue provided to a female.

Comparing the gene expression profiles of female X. birchmanni brains and olfactory epithelia according to social exposure treatment, we found greater differentiation in the expression of genes between birchmanni-exposed and malinche-exposed females than between either exposure group and socially isolated females. Specifically, we found that females exposed to adults of their own species developed relatively greater expression of genes related to immune response and olfactory and visual detection, whereas females exposed to adult X. malinche experienced a relative upregulation of genes related to synaptic transmission and neuronal plasticity. Together, these results suggest that the social environment plays a crucial role in the development of learned mating preferences through alterations at both the sensory periphery (olfactory epithelium) where signals are first detected, as well as within the brain itself where higher order processing of detected cues occurs.
